title-group.article-title: Factors associated with hemoglobin glycation index in adults with type 1 diabetes mellitus: The FGM‐Japan study

sec.title: Aims/Introduction
sec.p: The discrepancy between HbA1c and glucose exposure may have significant clinical implications; however, the association between the hemoglobin glycation index (HGI) and clinical parameters in type 1 diabetes remains controversial. This study aimed to find the factors associated with HGI (laboratory HbA1c − predicted HbA1c derived from the continuous glucose monitoring [CGM]).

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: We conducted a cross‐sectional study of adults with type 1 diabetes (n = 211, age 50.9 ± 15.2 years old, female sex = 59.2%, duration of CGM use = 2.1 ± 1.0 years). All subjects wore the CGM for 90 days before HbA1c measurement. Data derived from the FreeStyle Libre sensor were used to calculate the glucose management indicator (GMI) and glycemic variability (GV) parameters. HGI was defined as the difference between the GMI and the laboratory HbA1c levels. The participants were divided into three groups according to the HGI tertile (low, moderate, and high). Multivariate regression analyses were performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The female sex ratio, HbA1c, and % coefficient of variation (%CV) significantly increased over the HGI tertile, while eGFR and Hb decreased over the HGI tertile. In multivariate analysis, the factors associated with HGI were %CV and eGFR, after adjusting for HbA1c level and sex (R 2 = 0.44).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study demonstrated that HGI is associated with female sex, eGFR, and some glycemic variability indices, independently of HbA1c. Minimizing glycemic fluctuations might reduce HGI. This information provides diabetic health professionals and patients with personalized diabetes management for adults with type 1 diabetes.

abstract.p: This study aimed to investigate factors associated with the hemoglobin glycation index (HGI) indicating a discrepancy between HbA1c and glucose exposure in adults with type 1 diabetes. Female sex ratio, HbA1c, and % coefficient of variation (%CV) significantly increased over the HGI tertile, while eGFR and Hb decreased over the HGI tertile. In multivariate analysis, the factors associated with HGI were %CV and eGFR, after adjusting for HbA1c level and sex (R 2 = 0.44).

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development (AMED)

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The hemoglobin A1c (A1c) test, which indicates the average blood glucose level over the past 90 days, is used to diagnose diabetes and to evaluate a patient's level of glycemic control 1 . However, healthcare professionals often find a discrepancy between HbA1c and average blood glucose levels in routine clinical practice. The hemoglobin glycation index (HGI; laboratory A1c – predicted A1c) is a marker to quantify inter‐individual variation in glycosylation of hemoglobin 2 . In type 2 diabetes, a high HGI is associated with an increased risk of diabetic complications, cardiovascular disease, and mortality 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 . In a community‐based survey, a high HGI was associated with an increased risk of arterial hypertension 10 . This suggests that the HGI could be used clinically for a more personalized assessment of the risk of complications in type 1 diabetes 11 . High glycation phenotypes in people with type 1 diabetes result in a challenge for the interpretation of better glycemic control 12 . In people with type 1 diabetes, the association between clinical parameters and the HGI remains controversial 13 , 14 , 15 . This mechanism is not fully understood. In non‐diabetic people, the effects of inflammation on HbA1c were reflected by HGI 16 . HGI was also associated with telomere attrition through TNF‐α 17 . Therefore, understanding the discrepancy between glucose exposure and HbA1c levels might have some clinical implications in adults with type 1 diabetes. This study aimed to find the factors associated with HGI (laboratory HbA1c − predicted HbA1c derived from the continuous glucose monitoring [CGM]).

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: The FGM‐Japan study is a cross‐sectional study designed to evaluate the adherence to self‐monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) and the association of HGI with CGM metrics in adults with type 1 diabetes in a real‐world setting in Japan. This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the National Hospital Organization (NHO) Kyoto Medical Center (No. 19‐072) and registered (UMIN000039376).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants were recruited from a collaborating center between February 2020 and March 2022. The inclusion criteria were the following: (1) type 1 diabetes, (2) ≥3 months duration of CGM use, (3) age ≥20 years, and (4) attendance at a collaborating NHO center. Exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) non‐insulin therapy, (2) anti‐dementia drug treatment, and (3) inappropriate cases judged by the research coordinators or director.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Continuous glucose monitoring metrics 18 , 19 , 20 , which were collected over the past 90 days of FreeStyle Libre (Abbott Diabetes Care Inc., Alameda, CA, USA), were calculated if the CGM data were adequate (≥70%) 21 . Severe hypoglycemia (SH) episodes in the preceding year, hypoglycemic episodes in the preceding month was recorded. Impaired awareness of hypoglycemia (IAH) was determined using the Gold questionnaire. Information on diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy 22 , and diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) 23 were collected. Diabetic retinopathy was assessed by an ophthalmologist using retinal photography. Retinopathy was classified as absent, simple, pre‐proliferative, or proliferative. Nephropathy was classified as stage 1–5 based on the estimated glomerular filtration rate, the presence of albuminuria, or the hemodialysis stage. DPN was considered present following the criteria after the diagnosis of diabetes and excluding polyneuropathy, except for diabetic polyneuropathy; it was determined to be positive in the presence of at least two of the following three criteria: (1) subjective symptoms (numbness, pain, or dysesthesia in the bilateral lower extremities); (2) decreased or absent bilateral Achilles tendon reflexes; and (3) diminished bilateral vibratory sensation at the malleolus medialis (<10 s using a tuning fork at 128 Hz). Laboratory data (glycemic markers, blood cell parameters 24 , liver enzyme levels, and lipids) were collected. Serum osmolarity 25 , glycated albumin (GA)/HbA1c ratio 26 . G‐gap 27 , 28 , neutrophil‐to‐lymphocyte ratio, platelet‐to‐lymphocyte ratio 29 , the fibrosis‐4 index 30 were calculated. Lifestyle factors were also collected using a questionnaire 31 .

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The hemoglobin glycation index (formula: laboratory HbA1c − predicted HbA1c derived from CGM) were divided into high, moderate, and low tertiles. We performed statistical analyses: Fisher's exact test, the Cochran‐Armitage trend test, Student's t‐test, Mann–Whitney U test, analysis of variance with Tukey's test, Kruskal–Wallis test, Jonckheere‐Terpstra trend test, Pearson's correlation coefficient test, and linear regression analysis. Glycemic variability (GV) was calculated using gluvarpro and iglu R packages 32 , 33 . Cases with missing data were excluded from the analysis. Statistical significance was set at P < 0.05. The analysis was conducted using the R program version 4.1.2.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The study was conducted on 211 adults with type 1 diabetes (mean age, 50.9 ± 15.2 years; female, 59.2%; duration of CGM use, 2.1 ± 1.0 years). The participants were divided into three subgroups according to their HGI tertile (Table 1).

caption.p: Clinical characteristics of FGM‐Japan participants by HGI tertile

fn.p: P < 0.05 (vs lowest tertile). BMI, body mass index; BW, body weight; NDR, no diabetic retinopathy; PDR, proliferative diabetic retinopathy; PPDR, pre‐proliferative diabetic retinopathy; SDR, simple diabetic retinopathy; TDD, total daily dose of insulin.

sec.title: HGI and clinical characteristics
sec.p: Figure 1 shows a histogram of HGI, the mean (standard deviation [SD]) and median (interquartile range [IQR]) in the total population were 0.7 (SD: 0.5) and 0.7 (IQR: 0.3, 1.0), respectively. The ratio of female sex showed increasing HGI from lower to higher tertiles (Table 1). DPN tended to show increasing HGI from lower to higher tertiles. There was no difference in the severity of retinopathy and nephropathy among the HGI tertiles. The G‐gap showed an increasing HGI from the lower to higher tertiles; however, there was no difference in the GA/HbA1c ratio among the groups. Factors associated with DPN were age (OR 1.06 [95% CI 1.03–1.08]), HbA1c (OR 1.52 [95% CI 1.06–2.19]), and HGI (OR 2.26 [95% CI 1.18–4.33]), but not BMI (OR, 1.01 [95% CI 0.92–1.11]). The HbA1c, GA, and G‐gap values showed an increasing HGI from the lower to higher tertiles, although eGFR, Hb, MCH, and serum sodium levels decreased from the lower to higher tertiles (Table 2). There were no differences in eating, exercise, lifestyle, or sleep habits among the subgroups (Table 3). There was a significant correlation between HGI and HbA1c (r = 0.596, P < 0.001) and G‐gap (r = 0.310, P < 0.001). However, age and BMI were not associated with HGI (r = 0.124 and 0.096, P = 0.073 and 0.168, respectively). There was no association between a low MCV and HbA1c in female subjects (P = 0.914).

caption.p: Laboratory data of the study participants according to the HGI tertile

fn.p: P < 0.05 (vs moderate tertile). Alb, albumin; ALT, alanine transaminase; AST, aspartate aminotransferase; BUN, blood urea nitrogen; eGFR, estimated glomerular filtration rate; G‐gap, Glycation gap; GGT, gamma‐glutamyl transferase; HbA1c, glycated hemoglobin; HDL‐C, high‐density lipoprotein cholesterol; LDL‐C, low‐density lipoprotein cholesterol; MCH, mean corpuscular hemoglobin; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration; MCV, mean corpuscular volume; NLR, neutrophil‐to‐lymphocyte ratio; PLR, platelet‐to‐lymphocyte ratio; RBC, red blood cell; TG, triglyceride; TP, total protein; WBC, white blood cell.

caption.p: Lifestyle factors of the participants according to the HGI tertile

sec.title: HGI tertiles and CGM metrics
sec.p: The average daily risk range (ADRR) and CV showed an increasing HGI from the lower to higher tertiles. There was no difference in SD, MAGE, HBGI, LBGI, and MODD among the HGI tertiles (Table 4). As shown in Table 5, multivariate linear regression analysis identified female sex, HbA1c, CV, and eGFR as factors that could influence the HGI (R 2 = 0.44, P < 0.001). In a stepwise multivariate analysis, female sex (β = 0.221, P < 0.001), HbA1c (β = 0.331, P < 0.001), %CV (β = 0.012, P = 0.007), and eGFR (β = −0.003, P = 0.018) were associated with HGI (R 2 = 0.44, P < 0.001). There was no difference in the mean absolute relative difference (MARD) between the groups.

caption.p: CGM metrics of the participants according to the HGI tertile

fn.p: P < 0.05 (vs lowest tertile). ADRR, average daily risk range; GMI, glucose management indicator; HBGI, high blood glucose index; LBGI, low blood glucose index; MAGE, mean amplitude of glycemic excursions; MOOD, mean of daily differences; SD, standard deviation; TAR, time‐above‐range; TBR, time‐below‐range; TIR, time‐in‐range.
P < 0.05. CV, coefficient of variation; eGFR, estimated glomerular filtration rate; HbA1c, glycated hemoglobin; VIF, variance inflation factor.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This is the first study to examine the association of HGI with diabetic complications and CGM metrics in Japanese adults with type 1 diabetes. In this study, a high HGI was significantly associated with female sex, as reported previously in people with a high risk of diabetes 34 , 35 . The relationship between HGI and female sex was consistent across studies. The etiology of sex differences in HGI could be explained by heritable differences in erythrocyte lifespans 36 and glucose transport 37 .

sec.title: Association of HGI with GV and G‐gap
sec.p: Glycemic variability is an important metric to be considered when assessing glycemic control in clinical practice 38 . In this study, the most popular metrics of GV (%CV and ADRR) showed a significant increase over the HGI tertiles. Liu et al. 39 reported that GV influenced the relationship between GMI measured using the iPro™2 sensor and laboratory HbA1c in 91 adults with type 1 diabetes. This study indicated the association between HGI and G‐gap, which is an index of intracellular glycation of proteins. A small study of 36 patients with type 2 diabetes identified a strong correlation between the mean blood glucose (MBG) HGI and G‐gap 40 . In this study, eGFR was negatively associated with HGI.

sec.title: HGI and DPN
sec.p: This study shows an association between the HGI and DPN. In 1,441 people with type 1 diabetes, a high HGI based on MBG was associated with an increased risk of nephropathy and retinopathy, but the study did not check the association between HGI and neuropathy 13 . There were no differences in age, diabetes duration, unhealthy lifestyle (smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and low physical activity), lifestyle‐related disease (hypertension and dyslipidemia), and subclinical inflammation markers among groups. However, several risk factors for DPN have been reported in previous studies 41 . Bragd et al. 42 indicated that blood GV might be an important risk factor for the development of peripheral neuropathy in patients with type 1 diabetes, but another study based on SMBG did not confirm this association 43 . In a recent study from Korea and China, GV in CGM was independently associated with the presence of neuropathy in patients with type 2 diabetes 44 , 45 . In contrast, HGI was inversely associated with peripheral nerve conduction velocity (NCV) in 324 patients with type 2 diabetes 46 . However, NCV was not measured in this study. Since the role of the HGI in DPN remains unclear, reducing the HGI could become an important part of diabetes management, and its association with DPN should be established. Further examination including the measurement of NCV and reduction of HGI intervention, is required to confirm these issues in adults with type 1 diabetes in the future.

sec.title: Clinical implications
sec.p: The hemoglobin glycation index has been proposed as a marker for quantifying inter‐individual variation in Hb glycosylation. There are several formulas for HGI: FPG‐ 47 , 48 , MBG‐, and CGM‐based. MBG‐ or CGM‐based HGI are often used for patients with type 1 diabetes, while FBG‐based HGI are often used for the general population or patients with type 2 diabetes. A meta‐analysis indicated that a high FBG‐based HGI was associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and mortality in people with type 2 diabetes 3 . FBG‐based HGI is useful for hyperglycemia diagnosis in high‐risk patients or patients with type 2 diabetes because HGI reflects the difference between FBG and the estimated average glucose derived from HbA1c. The association of HGI with morbidity and mortality might be mainly mediated by the level of HbA1c. Conversely, for MBG‐based HGI, a seven‐sample glucose profile (before and after three main meals and bedtime), is an index of between‐individual differences in HbA1c adjusted for glycemia. However, it is difficult for patients with type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes to measure seven‐sample glucose every day in routine clinical practice. In recent decades, CGM technology has become increasingly popular and offers a variety of metrics. In this study, we adopted a CGM‐based HGI, which is relatively accurate, and the study indicated that a high HGI was associated with DPN and ADRR, a measure of hypo‐ and hyperglycemic risk. Careful attention should be paid to type 1 diabetes adults with high HGI as a potential risk, although the underlying mechanism is unclear.

sec.title: Strength and limitations
sec.p: The strength of this study is its long‐term CGM‐based data providing an ambulatory glucose profile. This study has several limitations, including its cross‐sectional design. We did not measure AGE, labile A1c 49 , or fructosamine. The concept of G‐gap using fructosamine proposed by Cohen et al. 50 was widely used for examining the association of G‐gap and diabetic complications. On the other hand, GA is another index for the evaluation of glycemia, which might be better compared with HbA1c and fructosamine. The main component of fructosamine is GA, but fructosamine contains other components such as glycated lipoprotein and glycated globulin. Recently, G‐gap using GA has been used for diabetes research 27 . GA was routinely measured as a glycemic control marker in people with type 1 diabetes and gestational diabetes in Japan 51 . Then, we adopted G‐gap using GA in this study. Some reports have shown that black participants have a higher HGI, independent of their diabetes status 16 . Whether Japanese individuals have a higher HGI is unknown. The generalizability of the results is limited by the target population (Japanese adults with type 1 diabetes). There are several conditions under which the HbA1c test can produce inaccurate results because of falsely low and high values 1 . There was no difference in the prevalence of anemia, diabetic nephropathy, FIB4 index, or excessive alcohol consumption, affecting falsely low HbA1c values among the groups. However, a falsely high HbA1c level can be due to iron deficiency anemia and hypertriglyceridemia. The absolute value of the correlation indicated the coefficient of determination. The HGI was moderately explained using HbA1c, with a moderate coefficient of determination (R 2 = 0.39). Iron storage depletion is usually identified by serum ferritin levels, but we did not measure serum ferritin in this study. Then, we adopted the mean corpuscular volume (MCV). Iron deficiency is the most common cause of microcytic anemia, which is defined as the presence of small red characterized by a low MCV (<83 fL) 52 . There was no association between a low MCV and HbA1c in females. The algorithm of glucose measurement by an intermittent‐scanning continuous glucose monitoring (isCGM) device has been improved recently. Therefore, further examination including the isCGM device with a new algorithm (third generation) and the serum ferritin are required to confirm these issues.

In conclusion, HGI is associated with female sex, DPN renal function, and some GV indices. The HGI calculated from CGM data is considered a convenient measurable indicator to assess the inter‐individual variation of HbA1c in the present era of CGM technology. Standardizing how the HGI is calculated would normalize the results between research studies and hospital laboratories and facilitate the clinical use of the HGI for assessing risk 2 , 12 . This information will help diabetic healthcare professionals and patients to personalize the management of glycemic control in adults with type 1 diabetes. However, the coefficient of determination (R 2 = 0.44) was less than half, and other factors influencing the HGI should be considered. Further examination, including the biokinetic model and other factors, is required to investigate the underlying mechanism of increasing HGI.

sec.title: DISCLOSURE
sec.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

Approval of the research protocol: The present study was approved by the ethics committee of the National Hospital Organization Kyoto Medical Center (No. 19‐072). This study conformed to the standards of the Declaration of Helsinki.
Informed consent: Informed consent or a substitute for it to be included in the study was obtained from all patients.
Registry and the registration no. of the study/trial: Trial registration number: University hospital Medical Information Network (UMIN) Center: UMIN000039376.
Animal studies: N/A.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

The FGM‐Japan study was completed with funding from the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development (AMED) (Grant number: 18ek0210104h0001, 19ek0210104h0002, 20ek0210104h0003) and Japan.
